subject: Re: How to use JUnit for multi-threaded code?
msgSnippet: ... native ... Now that I think about this, speaking of Java 1.5, why not see how the java.util.concurrent folks unit test their code?  On the concurrency
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kupci2" <kupci2@...> wrote:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Pat Farrell <pfarrell@> wrote:
> >
> > Java has been multi-threaded from the start, and Java 5 has
native
> API
> > support for things like Barriers that used to be rolled by a
> toolsmith
> > reading the O'Reilly "Java Threads" book.
> >
> > It is not clear to me how to use JUnit to test multi-thread
> applications.
> >
> > Is it possible?
> > Any hints and tips?
> >
> I've used Andy Schneider's Multithreaded Test Case with success:
> http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-12-2000/jw-1221-junit_p.html
>
> Also see this article, which has a few examples illustrating the
> problems running multithreaded tests in JUnit:
> http://today.java.net/pub/a/today/2003/08/06/multithreadedTests.html
>
Now that I think about this, speaking of Java 1.5, why not see how
the java.util.concurrent folks unit test their code? On the
concurrency list, usually members send out simple classes, consisting
of a main method, for illustrative purposes, but in fact they do use
JUnit for certain testing. Especially see the
JSR166TestCase.joinPool method, and the threadFailed variable for
ideas on how they extend JUnit to provide support for multithreaded
testing (similar idea to the links provided above):

http://dcl.mathcs.emory.edu/cgi-
bin/viewcvs.cgi/software/util/backport-util-concurrent/test/tck/


-Mike
